title: 106_hr1681
content: The Act may be cited as the "Major Drug Trafficking Prosecution Act of 1999". Congress finds that since the enactment of mandatory minimum sentencing for drug offenses, the Federal Bureau of Prisons budget increased significantly. Mandatory minimums have shifted discretion from judges to prosecutors, leading to disparities in sentencing. Additionally, African Americans are disproportionately represented in Federal drug convictions. After the implementation of mandatory minimums for crack cocaine offenses, African Americans faced significantly higher average drug offense sentences compared to whites. The average drug dealer holds a low-wage job and sells part-time for personal use. Time spent in prison does not impact recidivism rates, according to the Justice Department. The Attorney General must approve federal prosecutions for offenses involving illegal distribution or possession of controlled substances below specified amounts. Additionally, certain sentencing provisions are modified. Section 404 of the Controlled Substances Act is amended to remove specific sentencing guidelines, and Section 401(b) is also amended to adjust penalties for certain offenses involving controlled substances.
